div.p: This case-sensitive code system https://mitre.org/fhir/space-health/CodeSystem/space-physiological-effects-cs defines the following codes:

tr.td: A condition experienced by astronauts during initial exposure to microgravity, characterized by nausea, vomiting, headache, and general malaise
Bone mineral density loss specifically caused by exposure to microgravity during spaceflight
The loss of muscle mass and strength specifically caused by exposure to microgravity during spaceflight
The inability to maintain normal blood pressure and adequate cerebral perfusion while in an upright position after spaceflight
Changes in balance, coordination, and spatial orientation that occur during adaptation to microgravity
Motion sickness specifically occurring during spaceflight as the body adapts to microgravity
The movement of bodily fluids toward the head in microgravity, causing facial edema and congestion
The reduction in heart mass and decreased cardiac output resulting from extended exposure to microgravity
Changes in immune system function during spaceflight, potentially resulting in altered response to pathogens
Reduction in red blood cell mass during spaceflight
Changes in arterial structure and function during spaceflight
Expansion of spinal discs in microgravity, potentially leading to back pain and increased height
Elevated intraocular pressure associated with spaceflight

description.value: CodeSystem for space physiological effects not found in SNOMED CT

definition.value: A condition experienced by astronauts during initial exposure to microgravity, characterized by nausea, vomiting, headache, and general malaise

The inability to maintain normal blood pressure and adequate cerebral perfusion while in an upright position after spaceflight
Changes in balance, coordination, and spatial orientation that occur during adaptation to microgravity
Motion sickness specifically occurring during spaceflight as the body adapts to microgravity
The movement of bodily fluids toward the head in microgravity, causing facial edema and congestion
The reduction in heart mass and decreased cardiac output resulting from extended exposure to microgravity

Reduction in red blood cell mass during spaceflight
Changes in arterial structure and function during spaceflight
Expansion of spinal discs in microgravity, potentially leading to back pain and increased height
Elevated intraocular pressure associated with spaceflight
